threat_type.name: Human actors using physical means
threat_type.description: The threats in this category represent threats to the information asset that result from physical access to the asset or a container that hosts an information asset. They require direct action by a person and can be deliberate or accidental in nature.

threat_type.name: Human actors using technical means
threat_type.description: The threats in this category represent threats to the information asset via the organisation's technical infrastructure or by direct access to a container (technical asset) that hosts an information asset. They require direct action by a person and can be deliberate or accidental in nature.

threat_type.name: Other General Threats
threat_type.description: The threats in this category are problems or situations that are outside the control of an organisation. This category of threats includes natural disasters (e.g., floods, earthquakes) and interdependency risks. Interdependency risks include the unavailability of critical infrastructures (e.g., power supply).

threat_type.name: Technical Problems
threat_type.description: The threats in this category are problems with an organisation's information technology and systems. Examples include hardware defects, software defects, malicious code (e.g., viruses), and other system-related problems.

project_settings.name: Emergency Management - Alberta, Canada
project_settings.background:
RE Cares was a series of RE sessions and hackathon to work with real stakeholders to elicit and specify requirements, as well as to develop an initial design and prototype early features for a secure, private, instant messaging app to be used by emergency management personnel in Alberta, Canada. RE Cares is the initiative, along with the 2018 Requirements Engineering conference, intended to help society by adopting the latest software engineering research and practice as applied to important societal problems. RE Cares is a new undertaking to apply our RE expertise and beyond to social issues and/or philanthropic undertakings in order to show we care and to "do good". RE Cares is designed to elicit requirements from multiple stakeholders. We currently have a representative from Mutual Aid Alberta, a developer from Mutual Aid Alberta, a firefighter, and a government representative.
Mutual Aid Alberta as key stakeholders provided their previous and current challenges, and the current app that they request: a secure, private, instant messaging system that will run on their emergency portal, permitting emergency personnel from diverse provinces and locations to communicate in an integrated fashion. During the session, participants will raise questions in order to understand the different needs represented by the stakeholders. Then the participants will discuss requirements that were gathered ahead of time for the instant messaging app as well as continue to gather requirements from the stakeholders. Three techniques have been selected for use at RE Cares. Participants will apply their expertise in assisting with these three techniques to build specifications, to develop initial design, and to prototype a few features.
Since the initial work, this element of the project considers security risk and requirements in a system of systems context.
project_settings.strategic_goals: The goal of this area of the wider project is to model these scenarios as systems, and systems of systems integrating at different levels. The app may then be considered for security risks and requirements in a systems of systems context.
project_settings.scope: At a broad high-level, the scope considers each level contributing to the greater Canadian Emergency Management Systems - Federal, Provincial, Municipal, and communities.

environment.name: Emergency Management - Federal Level
environment.definition: A view of the Emergency Management - Federal Level, using the Canada as a whole.

role.name: The CEO of MAA
role.description: Responsible for providing advice to local governments and regional governments as well as working to improve our infrastructure, roads, emergency response equipment, emergency response procedures and information dissemination plans.

role.name: The On-site Supervisor
role.description: On-site supervisor of an Incident Command System. Responsible for following emergency response procedures and information dissemination plans while the onsite supervisor

role.name: The Emergency Medical Technician (EMT)
role.description: Emergency Medical Technicians (EMT) serve on an ambulance or fire crew, providing first response pre-hospital care that are considered basic life support treatments (BLT).

role.name: The On-site Incident Commander
role.description: To notify Supervisory Personnel of the incident and advise personnel in the area of any potential threat and/or initiate evacuation procedures.

role.name: The Firefighter
role.description: As a Firefighter I attend emergency scenarios.

asset.name: Residents Data
asset.description: Private Confidential Secure Access only. Key Contact's Name and 24-Hr Phone together with an alternate contact and information. Names of all family members (number of occupants, specifying age category) Location and Address. Identify anyone in the home with special needs e.g. transportation, contact issues, health, medical needs, language barrier, etc.
asset.significance: Important information supporting resource requirements, e.g. in an evaluation. In co-operation with the municipality, MAA we'll collect resident data from all residents in the community and can provide this to all operators and industry within the municipality.

asset.name: Operations Section Chief
asset.description: The Operations Section Chief (OSC) directly manages all incident tactical activities and implements the IAP. The OSC may have one or more deputies, preferably from other agencies in Multi-jurisdictional incidents. An OSC should be designated for each operational period and will have direct involvement in the development of the IAP for the next operational period of responsibility.
asset.significance: The Operations Section Chief (OSC) directly manages all incident tactical activities and implements the IAP. The OSC may have one or more deputies, preferably from other agencies in Multi-jurisdictional incidents. An OSC should be designated for each operational period and will have direct involvement in the development of the IAP for the next operational period of responsibility.

asset.name: Staging Area Manager
asset.description: Checks in all incoming resources, dispatches resources at the Operations Section Chief's request, and requests Logistics Section support, as necessary, for resources located in the Staging Area.
asset.significance: Checks in all incoming resources, dispatches resources at the Operations Section Chief's request, and requests Logistics Section support, as necessary, for resources located in the Staging Area.

asset.name: Planning Section Chief
asset.description: The Planning Section Chief oversees all incident-related data gathering and analysis regarding incident operations and assigned resources, conducts Planning Meetings, and prepares the IAP for each operational period. This individual will normally come from the jurisdiction with primary incident responsibility and may have one or more deputies from other participating jurisdictions.
asset.significance: The Planning Section Chief oversees all incident-related data gathering and analysis regarding incident operations and assigned resources, conducts Planning Meetings, and prepares the IAP for each operational period. This individual will normally come from the jurisdiction with primary incident responsibility and may have one or more deputies from other participating jurisdictions.

asset.name: Logistics Section Chief
asset.description: The Section Chiefs may have one or more deputies assigned, with the assignment of deputies from other agencies encouraged in the case of multi-jurisdictional incidents.
asset.significance: The Section Chiefs may have one or more deputies assigned, with the assignment of deputies from other agencies encouraged in the case of multi-jurisdictional incidents.

asset.name: Finance and Administration Section Chief
asset.description: The Section Chiefs may have one or more deputies assigned, with the assignment of deputies from other agencies encouraged in the case of multi-jurisdictional incidents.
asset.significance: The Section Chiefs may have one or more deputies assigned, with the assignment of deputies from other agencies encouraged in the case of multi-jurisdictional incidents.

asset.name: Area Commander
asset.description: The Area Commander is responsible for the overall direction of the IMTs assigned. This responsibility includes ensuring that conflicts are resolved, incident objectives established, and strategies selected for the use of critical resources. The Area Commander is also responsible for coordinating with Federal, Provincial, Territorial, First Nations, and local departments and agencies, as well as NGOs and the private sector.
asset.significance: The Area Commander is responsible for the overall direction of the IMTs assigned. This responsibility includes ensuring that conflicts are resolved, incident objectives established, and strategies selected for the use of critical resources. The Area Commander is also responsible for coordinating with Federal, Provincial, Territorial, First Nations, and local departments and agencies, as well as NGOs and the private sector.

asset.name: Area Command Logistics Chief
asset.description: The Area Command Logistics Chief provides facilities, services, and materials at the Area Command level and ensures the effective allocation of critical resources and supplies among the IMTs.
asset.significance: The Area Command Logistics Chief provides facilities, services, and materials at the Area Command level and ensures the effective allocation of critical resources and supplies among the IMTs.

asset.name: Area Command Planning Chief
asset.description: The Area Command Planning Chief collects information from various IMTs to assess and evaluate potential conflicts in establishing incident objectives, strategies, and priorities for allocating critical resources.
asset.significance: The Area Command Planning Chief collects information from various IMTs to assess and evaluate potential conflicts in establishing incident objectives, strategies, and priorities for allocating critical resources.

asset.name: Area Command Aviation Co-ordinator
asset.description: An Aviation Coordinator is assigned when aviation resources are competing for common airspace and critical resources, and works in coordination with incident aviation organizations to evaluate potential conflicts, develop common airspace management procedures, ensure aviation safety, and allocate critical resources in accordance with Area Command priorities.
asset.significance: An Aviation Coordinator is assigned when aviation resources are competing for common airspace and critical resources, and works in coordination with incident aviation organizations to evaluate potential conflicts, develop common airspace management procedures, ensure aviation safety, and allocate critical resources in accordance with Area Command priorities.

asset.name: Area Command Resources Unit Leader
asset.description: Tracks and maintains the status and availability of critical resources assigned to each incident under the Assistant Area Commander-Planning.
asset.significance: Tracks and maintains the status and availability of critical resources assigned to each incident under the Assistant Area Commander-Planning.

asset.name: Area Command Situation Unit Leader
asset.description: Monitors the status of objectives for each incident or IMT assigned to the Assistant Area Commander-Planning.
asset.significance: Monitors the status of objectives for each incident or IMT assigned to the Assistant Area Commander-Planning.

asset.name: Area Command Information Officer
asset.description: Provides coordination between incident locations and serves as the point of contact for media requests to the Area Command.
asset.significance: Provides coordination between incident locations and serves as the point of contact for media requests to the Area Command.

asset.name: Area Command Liaison Officer
asset.description: Helps maintain off-incident inter-agency contacts and coordination.
asset.significance: Helps maintain off-incident inter-agency contacts and coordination.

asset.name: Director of CEMA
asset.description: The Fire Chief, or authorized representative, shall be the Director of CEMA, and will: Designate an Acting Fire Chief. Activate the MEP and determine which members of CEMA shall report to the EOC and/or Site. Designate an Emergency Operations Center (EOC) Manager and an Incident Site Manager (ISM) as required.
asset.significance: The Fire Chief, or authorized representative, shall be the Director of CEMA, and will: Designate an Acting Fire Chief. Activate the MEP and determine which members of CEMA shall report to the EOC and/or Site. Designate an Emergency Operations Center (EOC) Manager and an Incident Site Manager (ISM) as required.

asset.name: Deputy Chief of CEMA
asset.description: Report to the EOC, or as assigned by the Director of CEMA. Act as the Director of CEMA when assigned.
asset.significance: Report to the EOC, or as assigned by the Director of CEMA. Act as the Director of CEMA when assigned.

asset.name: Incident Site Manager
asset.description: An Incident Site Manager will be appointed by the Director of CEMA, or designate, to be located on Site of the emergency, disaster, or catastrophe, in order to: Coordinate and facilitate the organization of the response to an emergency with Incident Commanders. This includes participating in decision-making, determining priorities, setting minor strategy and developing tactical directives to mitigate the immediate impacts of the emergency, disaster, or catastrophe. Assess the situation under existing and potential conditions by consulting with Incident Commander (IC's) and other agencies, take/authorize any action appropriate to preserve life, protect property, and otherwise mitigate the adverse effects of the emergency, disaster, or catastrophe. Coordinate with the EOC and the IC's to ensure that the necessary equipment, supplies, and personnel are available. Ensure Tactical Management Centres are aligned with site objectives
asset.significance: An Incident Site Manager will be appointed by the Director of CEMA, or designate, to be located on Site of the emergency, disaster, or catastrophe, in order to: Coordinate and facilitate the organization of the response to an emergency with Incident Commanders. This includes participating in decision-making, determining priorities, setting minor strategy and developing tactical directives to mitigate the immediate impacts of the emergency, disaster, or catastrophe. Assess the situation under existing and potential conditions by consulting with Incident Commander (IC's) and other agencies, take/authorize any action appropriate to preserve life, protect property, and otherwise mitigate the adverse effects of the emergency, disaster, or catastrophe. Coordinate with the EOC and the IC's to ensure that the necessary equipment, supplies, and personnel are available. Ensure Tactical Management Centres are aligned with site objectives

ICS Function - Operations
asset.description: Conducts tactical operations to carry out the plan develops the tactical objectives, organization, and directs all resources.
asset.significance: Conducts tactical operations to carry out the plan develops the tactical objectives, organization, and directs all resources.

asset.name: ICS Function - Planning
asset.description: Develops the action plan to accomplish the objectives, collects and evaluates information. Maintains resource status.
asset.significance: Develops the action plan to accomplish the objectives, collects and evaluates information. Maintains resource status.

asset.name: ICS Function - Logistics
asset.description: Provides support to meet incident needs, provides resources and all other services needed to support the incident.
asset.significance: Provides support to meet incident needs, provides resources and all other services needed to support the incident.

asset.name: ICS Function - Finance and Administration
asset.description: Monitors costs related to incident, provides accounting, procurement, time recording, and cost analyses.
asset.significance: Monitors costs related to incident, provides accounting, procurement, time recording, and cost analyses.

asset.name: ICS Function - Intelligence and Investigative Func
asset.description: A system for the collection, analysis, and sharing of information developed during intelligence and investigation efforts. The collection, analysis, and sharing of incident-related intelligence are important elements of ICS. Normally, operational information and situational intelligence are management functions located in the Planning Section.
asset.significance: A system for the collection, analysis, and sharing of information developed during intelligence and investigation efforts. The collection, analysis, and sharing of incident-related intelligence are important elements of ICS. Normally, operational information and situational intelligence are management functions located in the Planning Section.

asset.name: ICS Area Command
asset.description: Area Command is an organization to oversee the management of multiple incidents handled individually by separate ICS organizations or to oversee the management of a very large or evolving incident engaging multiple IMTs. An Agency Administrator or Executive or other public official with jurisdictional responsibility for the incident usually makes the decision to establish an Area Command. An Area Command is activated only if necessary, depending on the complexity of the incident and incident management span-of-control considerations.
asset.significance: Area Command is an organization to oversee the management of multiple incidents handled individually by separate ICS organizations or to oversee the management of a very large or evolving incident engaging multiple IMTs. An Agency Administrator or Executive or other public official with jurisdictional responsibility for the incident usually makes the decision to establish an Area Command. An Area Command is activated only if necessary, depending on the complexity of the incident and incident management span-of-control considerations.

asset.name: Staging Area
asset.description: Staging Areas are established for the temporary location of available resources. Staging Areas will be established by the Operations Section Chief to enable positioning of and accounting for resources not immediately assigned. A Staging Area can be any location in which personnel, supplies, and equipment can be temporarily housed or parked while awaiting operational assignment. Staging Areas may include temporary feeding, fueling, and sanitation services.
asset.significance: Staging Areas are established for the temporary location of available resources. Staging Areas will be established by the Operations Section Chief to enable positioning of and accounting for resources not immediately assigned. A Staging Area can be any location in which personnel, supplies, and equipment can be temporarily housed or parked while awaiting operational assignment. Staging Areas may include temporary feeding, fueling, and sanitation services.

asset.name: Resource Unit
asset.description: The Resources Unit makes certain that all assigned personnel and resources have checked in at the incident. Resources consist of personnel, teams, crews, aircraft, and equipment available for assignment to or employment during an incident. The Resources Unit maintains a system for keeping track of the current location and status of all assigned resources and maintains a master list of all resources committed to incident operations.
asset.significance: The Resources Unit makes certain that all assigned personnel and resources have checked in at the incident. Resources consist of personnel, teams, crews, aircraft, and equipment available for assignment to or employment during an incident. The Resources Unit maintains a system for keeping track of the current location and status of all assigned resources and maintains a master list of all resources committed to incident operations.

asset.name: Situation Unit
asset.description: The Situation Unit collects, processes, and organizes ongoing situation information; prepares situation summaries; and develops projections and forecasts of future events related to the incident. The Situation Unit prepares maps and also gathers and disseminates information and intelligence for use in the IAP. This Unit should be prepared to provide timely situation reports as scheduled or at the request of the Planning Section Chief or IC. This Unit may also require the expertise of technical specialists.
asset.significance: The Situation Unit collects, processes, and organizes ongoing situation information; prepares situation summaries; and develops projections and forecasts of future events related to the incident. The Situation Unit prepares maps and also gathers and disseminates information and intelligence for use in the IAP. This Unit should be prepared to provide timely situation reports as scheduled or at the request of the Planning Section Chief or IC. This Unit may also require the expertise of technical specialists.

asset.name: Demobilization Unit
asset.description: The Demobilization Unit develops an Incident Demobilization Plan that includes specific instructions for all personnel and resources that will require demobilization. This Unit should begin its work early in the incident, creating rosters of personnel and resources, and obtaining any missing information as check-in proceeds. Note that many municipal provided resources are local, and as such do not require specific demobilization instructions. Once the Incident Demobilization Plan has been approved, the Demobilization Unit ensures that it is distributed both at the incident and elsewhere as necessary.
asset.significance: The Demobilization Unit develops an Incident Demobilization Plan that includes specific instructions for all personnel and resources that will require demobilization. This Unit should begin its work early in the incident, creating rosters of personnel and resources, and obtaining any missing information as check-in proceeds. Note that many municipal provided resources are local, and as such do not require specific demobilization instructions. Once the Incident Demobilization Plan has been approved, the Demobilization Unit ensures that it is distributed both at the incident and elsewhere as necessary.

asset.name: Documentation Unit
asset.description: The Documentation Unit maintains accurate and complete incident files, including a complete record of the major steps taken to resolve the incident; provides duplication services to incident personnel; and files, maintains, and stores incident files for legal, analytical, and historical purposes. This Unit compiles and publishes the IAP and maintains the files and records that are developed as part of the overall IAP and planning function.
asset.significance: The Documentation Unit maintains accurate and complete incident files, including a complete record of the major steps taken to resolve the incident; provides duplication services to incident personnel; and files, maintains, and stores incident files for legal, analytical, and historical purposes. This Unit compiles and publishes the IAP and maintains the files and records that are developed as part of the overall IAP and planning function.

asset.name: Technical Specialists
asset.description: ICS is designed to function in a wide variety of incident scenarios that require the use of technical specialists. These personnel have special skills and are activated only when needed. Specialists may serve anywhere within the organization, including the Command Staff.
asset.significance: ICS is designed to function in a wide variety of incident scenarios that require the use of technical specialists. These personnel have special skills and are activated only when needed. Specialists may serve anywhere within the organization, including the Command Staff.

asset.description: Responsible for ensuring that required investigative personnel are made available expeditiously and that the necessary resources are properly distributed, maintained, safeguarded, stored, and returned, when appropriate.

CEMA works with other City departments, corporations, communities and non-profit agencies to increase Calgary's capacity to be prepared for and recover more quickly from a disaster.

asset.name: Tactical Management Centre
asset.description: Tactical Management Centres are facilities that provide direction and support to individual services during their regular business activities. These centres may also provide support to their own service when the MEP is activated. Tasks of field units engaged under MEP activation remain under the jurisdiction of Site Command. Tactical Management Centres often have excellent information-gathering systems and are invaluable to the success of multi-agency events.

persona.name: Wanda Baker - On-site Supervisor
persona.activities: I am responsible for following emergency response procedures and information dissemination plans while the onsite supervisor. In a typical incident day, I serve as the Incident Commander (IC), until relieved by a more senior person. I notify Supervisory Personnel and/or Incident Commander of the incident. I advise personnel in the area of any potential threat and/or initiate evacuation procedures. I eliminate potential ignition sources. I may initiate initial response actions if I am the first person on the scene. Restrict access to the incident scene and surrounding area as the situation demands Take any other steps necessary to minimize any threat to health and safety. Request medical assistance, if necessary. Verify substance released and obtain Safety Data Sheets, as necessary. Identify and isolate source to minimize product loss. Coordinate further response actions with Incident Commander and local responders.
persona.attitudes: I take appropriate personal protective measures. My biggest challenges are those things that cannot be controlled such as drought, irresponsible people who start fires, etc. I prefer to interact with vendors by email. I use the internet to research vendors or products. I search for information using Google. Then I look at the vendors sites. Sometimes I look at Amazon and EBay.
persona.aptitudes: I overcome these challenges by being prepared. I learn about new information for my job by reading various trade journals and magazines, reading current news stories on sites such as WSJ, Yahoo, MSNBC, I attend annual conferences and gain information there, I meet with consultants and learn from them. I read the emergency management journal????? I belong to the emergency responders union???? I also have Facebook and Twitter
persona.motivations: I am considered successful in my role if we are able to address emergencies effectively and efficiently. My job is measured by how well we provide assistance to the evacuees, victims, and first responders of emergencies.

persona_environment.name: Mutual Aid Alberta - App and Portal
persona_environment.narrative: Wanda is 41 and married with two kids. In here spare time she likes to read and shop online. As an On-site supervisor here job is measured by how well they provide assistance to the evacuees, victims, and first responders of emergencies. In a typical incident day, Wanda serves as the Incident Commander (IC), until relieved by a more senior person, then acts as a on-site supervisor.

persona_environment.narrative: Wanda is 41 and married with two kids. In here spare time she likes to read and shop online. persona.name: Edwin Smith - CEO
persona.activities: As the CEO of an emergency management non-profit (MMA), responsible for providing advice to local governments and regional governments as well as working to improve our infrastructure, roads, emergency response equipment, emergency response procedures and information dissemination plans. In a typical day, I meet with local and regional and national government officials; I meet with managers of other related nonprofits. I meet with management of first responders; I work on grant applications. I look for opportunities to improve our area infrastructure, mapping, and other related aspects in order to make our area safer and easier for emergency management service provision. I also meet with my personnel. I report to a Board of Directors. I have an administrative assistant and a Chief Financial Officer and a Chief Technical officer and two “line” managers who report to me.
persona.attitudes: I am considered successful in my role if we are prepared for emergencies and do not encounter unforeseen challenges when emergencies arise. My biggest challenges are those things that cannot be controlled such as drought, irresponsible people who start fires, etc. I overcome these challenges by being prepared and helping our community be prepared.
persona.aptitudes: I use my knowledge of emergency response procedures and grant writing requirements and procedures and I use a number of tools such as word processing tools, spreadsheets, GIS systems. I learn about new information for my job by reading various trade journals and magazines, reading current news stories on sites such as WSJ, Yahoo, MSNBC, I attend annual conferences and gain information there, I meet with consultants and learn from them. I read the emergency management journal. I belong to the emergency responders union. I also have Facebook and Twitter.
persona.motivations: I am considered successful in my role if we are prepared for emergencies and do not encounter unforeseen challenges when emergencies arise.
persona.skills: Of our area, My skills include communication (written and verbal), planning, networking, basic geographical knowledge of our area, knowledge of government standards and requirements for emergency response, knowledge of the local area and its residents.

persona_environment.name: Mutual Aid Alberta - App and Portal

persona_environment.narrative: As the CEO of an emergency management non-profit (MMA), responsible for providing advice to local governments and regional governments as well as working to improve our infrastructure, roads, emergency response equipment, emergency response procedures and information dissemination plans.

persona.name: Deedee Zone - EMT
persona.activities: In a typical day, I am on call or ride on the ambulance for 16 hours and sleep for 8 hours. I am responsible for performing EMT activities such as performing CPR. Serve on an ambulance or fire crew, providing first response pre-hospital care that are considered basic life support treatments (BLT). Gather and consider information on weather data, topography, fuel types, and fire behavior during suppression of wildland fire incidents. Perform CPR and use an AED. Bandage wounds. Stabilize head and neck injuries. Stabilize broken bones. Resuscitate drowning victims. Provide oxygen to patients. Perform emergency childbirth procedures. Assess health emergencies. Administer medication such as epinephrine and albuterol.
persona.attitudes: My biggest challenges are those things that cannot be controlled such as wind and other natural phenomenon in an emergency situation. I overcome these challenges by following the lead of my Chief who plans in advance and ensures that we are well prepared.
persona.aptitudes: I use my knowledge of emergency response procedures and I use a number of tools such as stethoscope, thermometer, blood pressure cuff.
persona.motivations: I am considered successful in my role if we are able to stabilize a patient and get the patient to the hospital in time for them to have a successful outcome.
persona.skills: My skills include assessing, stabilizing, administering.

persona_environment.name: Mutual Aid Alberta - App and Portal
persona_environment.narrative: In a typical day, I am on call or ride on the ambulance for 16 hours and sleep for 8 hours. I am responsible for performing EMT activities such as performing CPR. Serve on an ambulance or fire crew, providing first response pre-hospital care that are considered basic life support treatments (BLT).

persona_environment.name: Emergency Management - Municipal Level
persona_environment.narrative: In a typical day, I am on call or ride on the ambulance for 16 hours and sleep for 8 hours. I am responsible for performing EMT activities such as performing CPR. Serve on an ambulance or fire crew, providing first response pre-hospital care that are considered basic life support treatments (BLT).

persona.name: Marjorie Jones - Firefighter Incident Commander
persona.activities: In a typical incident day, I serve as the Incident Commander (IC). I take appropriate personal protective measures. I notify Supervisory Personnel of the incident. I advise personnel in the area of any potential threat and/or initiate evacuation procedures. Activate the Emergency Response team. Activate additional response contractors and local resources. Evaluate the Severity, Potential Impact, Safety Concerns, and Response Requirements based on the initial information provided by the First Person On-Scene. Confirm safety aspects at site, including need for personal protective equipment, sources of ignition, and potential need for evacuation. Communicate and provide incident briefings to company superiors, as appropriate. Coordinate/complete additional internal and external notifications. Communicate with Emergency Response Team, as the situation demands o Direct response and cleanup operations. Hotshot firefighter - Serve on a handcrew, prescribed fire crew, wildland fire engine, or helitack crew, performing wildland firefighting work and leading crews performing such work, i.e., wildland fire suppression and control activities including preparedness, prevention, monitoring, hazardous fuels reduction, and prescribed burning. Gather and consider information on weather data, topography, fuel types, and fire behavior during suppression of wildland fire incidents. Perform specialized duties such as water handling specialist, fully qualified chainsaw operator, and/or responsible for maintenance of specialized equipment used to respond to wildland urban interface/intermix situations. In a typical day, I fight fire for 16 hours and sleep for 8 hours
persona.attitudes: I am considered successful in my role if we are able to finish fire lines in advance of the fire and are able to quickly wrap up a dying fire. My biggest challenges are those things that cannot be controlled such as wind and other natural phenomenon. I overcome these challenges by following the lead of my Chief who plans in advance and ensures that we are well prepared.
persona.aptitudes: I use my knowledge of emergency response procedures and I use a number of tools such as shovel, rake, trimmers, hose. I learn about new information for my job by reading various trade journals and magazines, reading current news stories on sites such as WSJ, Yahoo, MSNBC. I attend annual conferences and gain information there, I meet with consultants and learn from them. I read the emergency management journal????? I belong to the emergency responders union???? I also have Facebook and Twitter.
persona.motivations: I report to my chief and have no reportees
persona.skills: Perform specialized duties such as water handling specialist, fully qualified chainsaw operator, and/or responsible for maintenance of specialized equipment used to respond to wildland urban interface/intermix situations. My skills include digging, chopping, carrying, spraying, orienteering

persona_environment.name: Mutual Aid Alberta - App and Portal
persona_environment.narrative: In a typical incident day, I serve as the Incident Commander (IC). I take appropriate personal protective measures. I notify Supervisory Personnel of the incident. I advise personnel in the area of any potential threat and/or initiate evacuation procedures. Activate the Emergency Response team. Activate additional response contractors and local resources.

persona_environment.name: Emergency Management - Municipal Level
persona_environment.narrative: In a typical incident day, I serve as the Incident Commander (IC). I take appropriate personal protective measures. I notify Supervisory Personnel of the incident. persona.name: Mark West - Evacuee
persona.activities: Government worker and resident in the line of the wildfires or flood or gas/chemical spill. I am responsible for my family and keeping them safe, fed, as calm as possible. My job is to help evacuate my family and gather our important possessions. In a typical day, I pack our possessions and ensure that we have that we have the supplies that we need to survive the wildfires/emergency situation. I 'report' to my wife and we have two kids.
persona.attitudes: I am considered successful in my role if we are able to safely evacuate from the fire/emergency area and get the supplies we need and the lodging we need, etc. and have as little stress or upheaval as possible. My biggest challenges are finding evacuation routes, finding supplies we may not have had at the house, getting gasoline for the car, getting food for our baby, getting insulin for our daughter if we are not able to return to normalcy in one week. I overcome these challenges by listening to the radio and TV. I learn about the current situation by watching local news stations, listening to the radio, and looking at our local government web page about the fire. I have Facebook,Twitter, Snap, and Instagram. But, I don't interact with vendors. I use the internet to research vendors or products. I search for information using Google. I use Amazon often.
persona.aptitudes: I use my knowledge of the local area and availability of supplies to make decisions about evacuating from the fire/emergency situation. I use a number of tools such as boxes, tape, maps.
persona.motivations: I am responsible for my family and keeping them safe, fed, as calm as possible. I am considered successful in my role if we are able to safely evacuate from the fire/emergency area and get the supplies we need and the lodging we need, etc. and have as little stress or upheaval as possible.
persona.skills: My skills include packing, shopping, planning, route planning.

persona.name: Dwight Parker - Public information officer
persona.activities: I am responsible for performing public information tasks. I report to the Incident Commander and have no reportees. Reviews and co-ordinates all information releases. Reviews the EOC Common Responsibilities Checklist Serves as the co-ordination point for all public information, media relations and internal. information sources for the EOC. Participates in the regional, state or federal Joint Information System, including management of the local Joint Information Center (JIC). Co-ordinates with incident Public Information Officers (PIO). In a typical day, I am on call for 16 hours and sleep for 8 hours.
persona.attitudes: My biggest challenges are lack of information and lack of ways to communicate and lack of cell service when needed. I don't interact with vendors. I use the internet to research vendors or products. I search for information using Google.
persona.aptitudes: I use my knowledge of emergency response procedures and I use a number of tools such as social media, word processors, websites, blogs. I learn about new information for my job by reading various trade journals and magazines, reading current news stories on sites such as WSJ, Yahoo, MSNBC, I attend annual conferences and gain information there, I meet with consultants and learn from them. I read the emergency management journal????? I belong to the emergency responders union???? I also have Facebook and Twitter.
persona.motivations: I am considered successful in my role if we are able to share accurate information as quickly as possible and prevent panic.
persona.skills: My skills include writing, speaking, organizing, motivating.

persona_environment.name: Mutual Aid Alberta - App and Portal

task_environment.narrative: As an emergency manager, I want to ask for a list of volunteers, e.g.Red Cross, that has the ability to make communication with evacuees who do not have access to our communication system, so that I can get messages to them.

usecase.name: App - Evacuee Alert
usecase.author: D
usecase.description: As a wildfire victim or someone affected by wildfire or disaster nearby, I need to be able to tell emergency personnel where I am and what I need so I can survive and-or escape.
